author: By Peter Beinart
title: Biden Thinks He Can Have It Both Ways on China. He’s Wrong.
description: The truth is, America’s national security depends on cooperation a lot more than competition.
content: The choreography has been exquisite. President Biden spent his first nine months in office trying to gain leverage over China: He patched up trade disputes with America’s allies. He hosted the first-ever in-person meeting of leaders of “The Quad,” which forged deeper ties between the United States, India, Japan and Australia, all of which sit on the periphery of Chinese power. He convinced NATO, for the first time in its history, to describe China as a challenge to “alliance security.” He cajoled Congress into spending a trillion dollars to rebuild U.S. infrastructure, which he pitched, in part, as a way to counter China. Then, earlier this week, on the very day he signed the infrastructure bill into law, he held his first formal meeting with President Xi Jinping. The message was unmistakable: The United States will work with China to address common challenges while competing from a position of strength.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: Buy Stocks to Prosper. Buy Bonds to Sleep at Night.
description: Do what it takes to stay invested in the stock market, our columnist says. Government bonds may help, even if they look unappealing now.
content: If you have kept money in the stock market consistently over the last few years, congratulations.

author: By Jon Pareles
title: C. Tangana, un rapero español que rompe géneros
description: Con un recorrido por la música de generaciones pasadas y un surtido transcontinental de colaboradores, el álbum “El madrileño” insiste en que la música de España no debe estar aislada ni ser elitista.
content: C. Tangana —cuyo nombre de pila es Antón Álvarez Alfaro— rompió los confines de género de la música urbana en su álbum de 2021 El madrileño. Con un recorrido por la música de generaciones pasadas y un surtido transcontinental de colaboradores, el álbum insiste en que la música de España no debe estar aislada ni ser elitista. Para reivindicar la tradición española, cuenta con guitarristas y cantantes flamencos de primera fila: Antonio Carmona, Diego del Morao, Israel Fernández, La Húngara. Y de América cuenta con el cantautor uruguayo Jorge Drexler, la mexicana Natalia Lafourcade y el mexicano-estadounidense Omar Apollo, cuyo dúo con Tangana, la balada de desamor “Te olvidaste”, está nominado en la categoría de Grabación del año. Su segmento promete abarcar mucho terreno estilístico.

description: La canción se ha convertido en la banda sonora de un movimiento creciente de protesta en Cuba. Ahora está nominada a dos premios Grammy Latinos.
content: CIUDAD DE MÉXICO — En julio, cuando miles de personas marcharon por toda Cuba en una manifestación impresionante contra el régimen comunista, muchas gritaron y corearon un estribillo común: “¡Patria y vida!”.

content: WASHINGTON — In March 2010, with Tea Party activists protesting loudly in the hallways of Capitol Hill and the political wind in their faces, 34 House Democrats — including Representative Stephen F. Lynch of Massachusetts — broke with their president to vote against passage of the Affordable Care Act.

title: The F.D.A. authorizes Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna booster shots for all adults.

content: For many years, one of the biggest concerns of minor league baseball players was where they would live. Often paid below minimum wage, they frequently jammed several beds into one apartment. Some would sign leases in one minor league city only to be stuck with those obligations when they got sent to another level of the minors.

content: When Jessica Slice, the writer of this week’s Modern Love essay, first started dating David, a man who had embraced her and her disability, she began to feel suffocated by his thoughtful gestures and nurturing nature. content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department indicted two Iranian hackers on Thursday for seeking to influence  the 2020 election with a clumsy effort to intimidate voters, just a day after the nation’s cyberdefense authorities warned of an escalating Iranian effort to insert malicious code into the computer networks of hospitals and other critical infrastructure.

title: China’s Influence Looms Over Blinken’s Africa Visit
description: On a stop in Nigeria, the secretary of state said the U.S. would no longer treat African countries as pawns in a global game. But American competition with Beijing was hard to overlook.
content: ABUJA, Nigeria — When Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken drove into Nigeria’s capital Abuja from the airport on Thursday, his motorcade zoomed past the China Chamber of Commerce in Nigeria building, a domed, almost palace-like structure along the expressway.

title: El artista con más nominaciones este año: Camilo
description: El cantante y compositor colombiano de gran bigote tiene diez nominaciones en los Grammy Latinos.
content: Camilo, de apellido Echeverry, el cantante y compositor colombiano de gran bigote, tiene diez nominaciones en los Grammy Latinos; son tantas que, en dos de las principales categorías, Grabación y Canción del año, está nominado dos veces. Esto se debe a que ha colaborado con varios artistas, ayudando a escribir un tema para su suegro, Ricardo Montaner, y colándose en la categoría regional mexicana con “Tuyo y mío”, una canción que escribió y grabó con un destacado grupo norteño, Los Dos Carnales.

author: By Patrick J. Lyons
title: The jury acquitted Kyle Rittenhouse on all of these five counts.
description: Kyle Rittenhouse was cleared of criminal culpability in the shooting of three white men, two of them fatally, during protests on Aug. 25, 2020.
content: A jury in Kenosha, Wis., acquitted Kyle Rittenhouse, a white teenager, on five felony counts on Friday, clearing him of criminal culpability in the shooting of three white men, two of them fatally, during street protests in the city on Aug. 25, 2020, over the shooting of a Black man by a white police officer.

author: By Vivian Yee
title: In Welcoming Prince Charles, Egypt’s Leader Sends a Message
description: The prince and his wife, Camilla, made Egypt their first foreign destination since the pandemic. Vestiges of British colonialism aside, they saw something new.
content: GIZA, Egypt — The royal visit was tightly choreographed. The Egyptian authorities closed the roads, cleared the trash and banished the camel drivers, hawkers and tourists, keen to showcase the pyramids to Prince Charles and Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall. But nobody accounted for the stray dog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Wisconsin Republicans Push to Take Over the State’s Elections
description: Led by Senator Ron Johnson, G.O.P. officials want to eliminate a bipartisan elections agency — and maybe send its members to jail.
content: Republicans in Wisconsin are engaged in an all-out assault on the state’s election system, building off their attempts to challenge the results of the 2020 presidential race by pressing to give themselves full control over voting in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Craig Brown

description: “Capote’s Women,” by Laurence Leamer, recounts the author’s intimate friendships with some of midcentury America’s most glamorous women — and what happened when he decided to depict them in his fiction.
content: CAPOTE’S WOMENA True Story of Love, Betrayal, and a Swan Song for an EraBy Laurence Leamer

title: U.S. Is ‘Considering’ Diplomatic Boycott of Beijing Olympics, Biden Says
description: A boycott would mean that government officials would not attend the Winter Games in February, though it would not prevent U.S. athletes from competing.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden said on Thursday that the United States was considering a diplomatic boycott of the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing, as pressure grows to hold China accountable for human rights abuses.

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Yannick Nézet-Séguin Is New York’s Conductor Now
description: After facing anger during a prolonged labor dispute, the Met Opera’s music director has returned to the podium, emphasizing new work.
content: The set for “Porgy and Bess” had been pushed to the back of the Metropolitan Opera’s stage on a recent Wednesday morning, and in front, lines of chairs and music stands had been set up. The company’s orchestra and chorus were coming together for the first time with the cast of “Eurydice” — a recent adaptation of Sarah Ruhl’s wistful play, with music by Matthew Aucoin — to run through the score in what’s known as a sitzprobe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Going Beyond the Inflation Headlines
description: This isn’t the inflation you were looking for.
content: Early this year some prominent economists warned that President Biden’s American Rescue Plan — the bill that sent out those $1,400 checks — might be inflationary. People like Larry Summers, who was Barack Obama’s top economist, and Olivier Blanchard, a former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, aren’t unthinking deficit hawks. On the contrary, before Covid hit, Summers advocated sustained deficit spending to fight economic weakness, and Blanchard was an important critic of fiscal austerity in the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis.

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Art Dealer Pleads Guilty to Wire Fraud Charges in $86 Million Scam
description: Prosecutors said Inigo Philbrick, who admitted he duped investors who joined him in the purchase of blue-chip art, took advantage of the opacity of the art market.
content: For years Inigo Philbrick, a young art dealer with a gallery in the Mayfair district in London, was a brash fixture within the world of postwar and contemporary art.

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: What If Elon Musk Wants to Build a Rocket on the Roof of the Dakota?
description: A billionaire’s plans for his prewar penthouse spark fears of slippery slope scenarios on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.
content: The most riveting — and frequently delicious — evocation of upper-class class warfare came to us this week not via an episode of “Succession” but rather during a Zoom hearing, more than three hours long, of New York’s Landmarks Preservation Commission. The matter at hand was whether the city ought to let a billionaire hedge-fund manager build a two-story glass pavilion above the top-floor apartment he owns in a 1927 building in Manhattan. But really it was about where the retaining wall ought to be erected against the desires of the magnificently wealthy to configure the world precisely to their specifications.

content: In September, on one of the first days that felt like fall, we drove from our house in Rhode Island to my father’s house in Massachusetts to spend the weekend. It is still hard for me to write or say “my father’s house.” Until recently, it was “my parents’ house,” but my mother died in June after a short illness, and her simple gray purse no longer sits on the hall table.

content: The male Bornean rock frog cannot scream over the sound of a waterfall. Instead, he threatens other frogs with his feet. content: Welcome. It’s the weekend before Thanksgiving, and for some of us, that means it’s a weekend of preparation. If you’re expecting company, you might be cooking or cleaning. You might be stuffing a turkey or stuffing two years of work-from-home detritus into closets in order to make your place presentable. description: Alice Childress’s 1955 play about power and race in the theater is a satire and a tragedy that deserves to be a classic.
content: So far this season, five plays by Black authors have opened on Broadway, each with something urgent to say. Whether despairing (“Pass Over”) or lighthearted (“Chicken & Biscuits”), broadly representative (“Thoughts of a Colored Man”) or laser-beam specific (“Lackawanna Blues”), they are talking to us now, like a newspaper come to life. Like newspapers, too, they are remade every day; when I caught up with “Thoughts of a Colored Man” recently, it had been updated with a hot take on the Kyle Rittenhouse trial.

content: Economists and epidemiologists need to get along. When economists bicker with epidemiologists about the best policy responses to the Covid-19 pandemic, policymakers get confused, and the public suffers. So it’s good that there’s a new effort to reconcile them. It takes the form of a manifesto released by 11 scholars this month: a National Bureau of Economic Research working paper with the subtitle “Bringing Epidemiologists and Economists Together.”

title: A C.D.C. study finds stillbirths are higher in pregnant women with Covid.

title: After 15 Months in U.S. Prisons, She Now Sits in Russia’s Parliament
description: Maria Butina, convicted of serving as an unregistered foreign agent before and after the 2016 election, insists she “wasn’t a spy” and that her Duma seat is “not a reward.” Her critics call her a Kremlin “trophy.”
content: MOSCOW — When Russia’s lower house of Parliament, or Duma, assembled last month for the first time following elections in September, one of its newest members was a name more familiar in the United States than in her home country.

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: How a Macy’s Parade Executive Producer Spends His Sundays
description: These days, Will Coss splits his time between family activities and planning the annual event that rings in the holiday season.
content: Will Coss oversees the design, construction and execution of the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade. The live annual extravaganza — which, because of the pandemic, was produced last year for television only — involves 300 pounds of glitter, 200 pounds of confetti, 240 gallons of paint and 15 giant helium balloons. This year the parade, which starts along Central Park West in Manhattan and ends in front of the Macy’s flagship at Herald Square, will welcome back the crowds. “I have to say, the excitement of where we are in the season and how it’s coming together is something that I’m actually really appreciating,” he said.

content: Inside Good Room, a nightclub in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, people were dancing to techno, sweating off their makeup and mingling with strangers, while outside, rain poured down on a line of partygoers that snaked down the block. content: Where is Peng Shuai?

author: By Sarah Seltzer
title: Not All Religious People Oppose Abortion
description: Jewish tradition prioritizes  the life of the mother over the fetus. Are our voices being heard?
content: Nearly 30 years ago, my mother was one of the hundreds of thousands of people who attended the 1992 March for Women’s Lives in Washington, D.C. It was a pivotal moment for abortion rights at the Supreme Court, which was about to hear arguments in the case Planned Parenthood v. Casey. Though she left me at home, the words on her sign — “Every child a wanted child” — made an impression. So did the fact that the buses to Washington were chartered by our synagogue. When she returned, I wore the neon pink “Choice” hat she’d bought to my classroom at Jewish day school and began to spread the word.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Can a Machine Learn Morality?
description: Researchers at a Seattle A.I. lab say they have built a system that makes ethical judgments. But its judgments can be as confusing as those of humans.
content: Researchers at an artificial intelligence lab in Seattle called the Allen Institute for AI unveiled new technology last month that was designed to make moral judgments. They called it Delphi, after the religious oracle consulted by the ancient Greeks. Anyone could visit the Delphi website and ask for an ethical decree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lovia Gyarkye
title: Toyin Ojih Odutola’s Mesmeric Alternate Universes
description: With her richly detailed narrative drawings, the artist creates vivid fictional worlds that ask questions about our own, and about the nature of storytelling itself.
content: Conversations with the Nigerian American artist Toyin Ojih Odutola tend to mirror the curious mood evoked in her ballpoint, pencil and charcoal drawings. They are adventurous, textured with abrupt tangents and suffused with humor. You might begin by gushing about Michaela Coel’s 2020 HBO mini-series, “I May Destroy You,” only to end up contemplating the history of precolonial Nigeria. Along the way, you might consider Nina Simone’s 1969 performance of “To Be Young, Gifted and Black,” captured in Questlove’s 2021 documentary “Summer of Soul”; laugh about the age-old beef between Nigerians and Ghanaians; lament tokenism in the creative industries; and eventually rejoice in the power of Octavia Butler’s mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: ‘Woke Left Mob’ Influenced Jury in Trial of Arbery Murder Suspects, Lawyer Says
description: The defense lawyer for one of three men accused of murdering Ahmaud Arbery unsuccessfully moved for a mistrial. Closing arguments are scheduled for Monday in Brunswick, Ga.
content: ATLANTA — With closing arguments in the trial of the men accused of murdering Ahmaud Arbery looming, the defense lawyer who prompted widespread criticism for trying to keep Black preachers like the Rev. Al Sharpton out of the courtroom moved on Friday for a mistrial, arguing that demonstrators outside the courtroom amounted to a “woke left mob” who were unduly influencing the jury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa, Giulia Heyward and Richard Fausset
title: Prosecutor Challenges Assailant on Whether Arbery Posed a Threat
description: Before Travis McMichael pointed his gun at Ahmaud Arbery, Mr. Arbery had not yelled at him or brandished a weapon, Mr. McMichael acknowledged under cross-examination.
content: BRUNSWICK, Ga. — A prosecutor’s cross-examination of Travis McMichael, the man who fatally shot Ahmaud Arbery, raised questions on Thursday about the defendant’s contention that Mr. Arbery presented a threat to him, and revealed social media posts that Mr. McMichael had made before the killing in which he described crime suspects as “vermin.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin
title: Michigan recommends that all residents older than the age of 2 wear a face mask indoors.
description: The advisory comes as the state tackles its highest surge of virus cases since the pandemic began.
content: As Michigan confronts the most severe rise in recent coronavirus cases per capita in the United States, the state’s health officials announced on Friday that they will issue a face mask advisory in an effort to hamper the virus’s spread ahead of the holidays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Biden’s Supreme Court Commission Shows Interest in Term Limits for Justices
description: But in newly released materials, members of the panel acknowledged “profound disagreement” over the wisdom of adding more justices to the court.
content: WASHINGTON — The most complete look yet at the ongoing work of President Biden’s Supreme Court commission showed its continuing interest in imposing terms limits on justices, while also noting “profound disagreement among commissioners” over whether court expansion would be wise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Tensions ease at the Poland-Belarus border.
content: The Belarusian authorities yesterday cleared the encampments at the country’s border with Poland, where thousands of migrants had been living in frigid and increasingly squalid conditions, leaving a wasteland of garbage, abandoned tents and smoldering fires. The camps had become a major flash point that has raised tensions across Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Roosevelt Statue to Head to Presidential Library in North Dakota
description: The American Museum of Natural History’s memorial, which has stirred objections as a symbol of colonialism and racism, is planned for display at a library opening in 2026.
content: In June, the New York City Public Design Commission made its decision: After more than 80 years presiding over the entrance to the American Museum of Natural History, the bronze statue of Theodore Roosevelt, on horseback and flanked by a Native American man and an African man, was coming down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Transfer Rumors From Another World
description: Talk about stars headed to Barcelona and Real Madrid conveniently leaves out an important fact: Neither club can afford them at the moment.
content: Everything starts with the interviews. Mohamed Salah granted the first, to the Spanish newspaper AS, last December. He talked about his career, his ambitions for the season. He demurred when asked if he would finish his career with Liverpool. He offered a couple of placatory bromides about the continuing virility of Real Madrid and Barcelona.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Slice
title: He Cared About Me, So I Broke Up With Him
description: When you’re used to the roller-coaster emotions of bad relationships, it can be hard to believe in anything else.
content: David said that he knew I was interested because of my body language. I had turned to face him on the small wooden bench, tucking my feet under me and resting my arm on the backrest. He was carrying a backpack and talked about Studs Terkel and asked if I wanted to borrow Joan Didion’s “Slouching Towards Bethlehem.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Boosted, Not Basted: Biden Pardons 2 Turkeys in Thanksgiving Tradition
description: “Peanut Butter and Jelly were selected based on their temperament, appearance, and, I suspect, vaccination status,” the president said.
content: WASHINGTON — There are few rituals in President Biden’s Washington that the coronavirus has not touched, that partisan contagion has not warped and that a collective sense of American exhaustion has not endangered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Isabelia Herrera, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Earl Sweatshirt Exhibits His Evolution, and 14 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by FKA twigs, Makaya McCraven, Hazel English and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon give us an excellent reason to eat and be merry.
content: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage will serve solvers well during the last few weeks of 2021, when our thoughts turn to retrospection and our diets turn to casseroles and cookies. Its author, Christoph Wilhelm Friedrich Hufeland, was a well-known German physician and naturopath in the 18th and 19th centuries. An early proponent of macrobiotics and an advocate for mental health care as a solution to poverty, Hufeland wrote several manuscripts about health, including the source of this excerpt, “The Art of Prolonging Life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denny Lee
title: Lorde Performs at Guggenheim Gala
description: And the Alzheimer’s Association holds a jazzy benefit.
content: The Guggenheim International Gala took place Nov. 17 with a black-tie dinner and a performance by Lorde. The gala, which was sponsored by Dior, honored Etel Adnan, Jennie C. Jones, Cecilia Vicuña, Gillian Wearing, and Phyllis and Bill Mack. And the Alzheimer’s Association raised more than $600,000 for Alzheimer’s research and care at its fund-raising dinner on Nov. 15 at Jazz at Lincoln Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: How to Ease the Worry of Holiday Gathering
description: For many people, coping with the anxiety of going out and about may be the hardest part of adjusting to this next phase of pandemic life.
content: The last time I traveled on a plane was in February 2020, when I brought home a severe case of the flu that felled me for three weeks. (A flu test confirmed my illness.) I had never been so sick in my life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Lawrence K. Altman, M.D
title: Biden Declared ‘Healthy’ and ‘Vigorous’ After His First Presidential Physical
description: Vice President Kamala Harris became the first woman to assume acting presidential duties, while President Biden underwent a colonoscopy.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s personal physician said on Friday that he was a “healthy, vigorous, 78 year old” who was fit to carry out his duties, after the president underwent a full medical evaluation and briefly transferred powers to the vice president so he could undergo a colonoscopy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Three Hanukkah Desserts That Skip the Fryer
description: Melissa Clark’s oil-imbued recipes, for lemon curd, chocolate cake and Greek honey cookies, are a sweet way to celebrate the holiday.
content: Every winter, I look forward to reveling in the fried food frenzy of latkes and jelly doughnuts called sufganiyot that is Hanukkah in my home. But, after a few grease-splattered days, I’ve had enough. Not of Hanukkah — that goes on for eight gelt-filled nights — but of frying. The question is, what else can I serve to celebrate the holiday?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judy Mandell
title: They Fell for Each Other Over a Fall Lunch
description: When Angela Schiller agreed to meet Robert Swift Jr. for a first date, she suggested a low key outdoor brown bag lunch.
content: Angela Schiller and Robert Swift Jr. first noticed each other in August 2015 at a Black Faculty and Staff Caucus function hosted by Kennesaw State University near Atlanta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Webster Ayuso
title: People Like Her Didn’t Exist in French Novels. Until She Wrote One.
description: Fatima Daas’s debut book explores the writer’s conflicted identities as a lesbian, Muslim woman with an immigrant background. In France, it was an unlikely literary hit.
content: PARIS — Fatima Daas was used to not reading about people like her. Her debut novel was a chance to remedy this.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Cambodia’s reopening is propelled by vaccinations.
description: Tourism-dependent businesses have struggled to make ends meet without visitors.
content: Cambodia reopened for fully vaccinated tourists from overseas this week without quarantine after a nationwide campaign succeeded in achieving one of the world’s highest vaccination rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: The company that produced ‘Parasite’ has bought Endeavor’s scripted content arm.
description: Endeavor was forced to reduce its ownership stake in its scripted content business as a result of a settlement with the Writers Guild of America.
content: The South Korean media conglomerate whose entertainment arm produced the winner of the 2019 Oscar for best picture, “Parasite,” has acquired a majority stake in the scripted arm of Endeavor Content, a subsidiary of the entertainment company Endeavor Group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: New in Paperback: ‘The Revolution According to Raymundo Mata’ and ‘This Is Not My Memoir’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: THE LANGUAGE OF THIEVES: My Family’s Obsession With a Secret Code the Nazis Tried to Eliminate, by Martin Puchner. (Norton, 288 pp., $17.95.) This “deeply personal project” probes “the meaning of language and family, inheritance and debt,” as our reviewer, Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim, put it. The title refers to Rotwelsch, a mix of Yiddish, Hebrew and repurposed German that antisemites cited to link Jews and crime (though most of its itinerant speakers were not Jewish and their “secret code” was not about crime).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Tips for a successful Thanksgiving.
content: All adults in the U.S. who received two doses of the Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines at least six months ago are now eligible for a booster shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Elite Wine Group Moves to Expel 6 Members in Sexual Harassment Inquiry
description: The American chapter of the Court of Master Sommeliers says it investigated 22 members. But at least one woman who came forward feels that’s not enough.
content: The American chapter of the Court of Master Sommeliers, one of the world’s most influential wine organizations, is moving to expel six men accused of a variety of sexual-misconduct offenses, after a nine-month investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: In N.W.S.L. Season to Forget, One Last Day to Cheer
description: After the Washington Spirit and Chicago Red Stars meet for the championship, their league will enter the most consequential off-season in its history.
content: To call the Washington Spirit’s season turbulent would be an understatement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Assembly Report on Cuomo Contains Grounds for Impeachment, Lawmaker Says
description: A report set to be made public next week sheds new light on the Cuomo administration’s manipulation of nursing home death data and the former governor’s $5.1 million book deal.
content: An investigation by the New York State Assembly Judiciary Committee has found that former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s administration “materially misrepresented” the extent of deaths that occurred in nursing homes in the early months of the coronavirus pandemic, according to an assemblyman who reviewed the report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Johnson
title: How H.G. Wells Predicted the 20th Century
description: Charles Johnson reviews Claire Tomalin’s latest biography, “The Young H.G. Wells: Changing the World.”
content: THE YOUNG H. G. WELLSChanging the WorldBy Claire Tomalin
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman, Dan Hinkel and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Jury in Kyle Rittenhouse Trial Has Deliberated for 23 Hours With No Verdict
description: The length of time spent suggests that the jurors may have clashed on the complex decisions they face. They were expected to resume deliberations on Friday morning.
content: KENOSHA, Wis. — The jurors in the Derek Chauvin murder trial in Minneapolis deliberated in April for 10 hours. In 1995, a jury in the O.J. Simpson trial delivered a verdict in less than four hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Rev. W. Sterling Cary, Pioneering Black Churchman, Dies at 94
description: He embraced what became known as Black liberation theology and, in 1972, became the first Black leader of the National Council of Churches.
content: The Rev. Dr. W. Sterling Cary, who boldly joined other Black religious leaders in 1966 in seeking to reconcile nonviolence and demands for Black Power, and who was later elected the first Black president of the National Council of Churches, died on Sunday at his home in Flossmoor, a Chicago suburb. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: WNYC Retracts Four Articles on Its News Site, Gothamist
description: In a new episode of turmoil at the radio station, the author of the articles was reassigned.
content: Gothamist, the news site of the New York public radio station WNYC, deleted four articles in the last week of October, replacing each one with an editor’s note.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: The C.E.O. of Afiniti, an A.I. start-up, steps down after accusations of sexual assault.
description: Zia Chishti resigned from the artificial-intelligence company he founded after a former employee accused him of sexual misconduct.
content: The chief executive of Afiniti, an artificial-intelligence software firm, has resigned, the company announced on Thursday, two days after a former employee testified before a congressional committee that the executive had sexually assaulted and beat her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Curry’s 3-Point Bonanza Has Golden State Bouncing Back
description: A turnaround early this season has come with Stephen Curry reasserting why he is the best 3-point shooter in basketball history.
content: Stephen Curry going for 40, the Golden State Warriors at the top of the league: We’re talking 2016 or so, right? No, try 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Former Professor Is Indicted in ‘Arson Spree’ in California
description: Prosecutors say Gary Stephen Maynard set four fires this summer as one of the largest wildfires in California history raged nearby.
content: A former university professor has been indicted on charges that he set four wildfires in national forests while on an “arson spree” in California this summer, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Prosecutors rest their case in the trial of Theranos’s Elizabeth Holmes.
description: For the past 11 weeks, prosecutors revealed emails from desperate investors. They held up falsified documents side-by-side with the originals. They called dozens of witnesses who lobbed accusations of deceit and evasiveness.
content: For the past 11 weeks, prosecutors revealed emails from desperate investors. They held up falsified documents side-by-side with the originals. They called dozens of witnesses who lobbed accusations of deceit and evasiveness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: The Case Against Loving Your Job
description: Will work ever love us back? Two millennials disagree.
content: The compulsion to be happy at work “is always a demand for emotional work from the worker,” writes Sarah Jaffe. “Work, after all, has no feelings. Capitalism cannot love. This new work ethic, in which work is expected to give us something like self-actualization, cannot help but fail.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Political fund-raisers are basing appeals to donors on the Rittenhouse trial.
description: Emails from both supporters and critics of Mr. Rittenhouse seeking donations reflect how much the case has become a political touchstone.
content: As the jury deliberates in Kyle Rittenhouse’s homicide trial, fund-raising emails from both his supporters and his critics increasingly are reflecting how much the case has become a political touchstone as well as a highly charged legal proceeding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
title: Bloodied Venezuelan Opposition Returns to Elections for First Time in Years
description: With little hope of a fair vote, opposition candidates take a desperate risk to gain any edge against Venezuela’s entrenched autocrat, Nicolás Maduro.
content: UPATA, Venezuela — His opposition to Venezuela’s authoritarian leader had left him bloodied by government thugs, forced him into hiding in a foreign embassy and pushed him into a nearly two-year exile in Italy, where he sold bread in a train station as he thought of home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Concern and Anger Build Over Missing Athlete’s Sexual Assault Allegations
description: The case of Peng Shuai has prompted the women’s tennis tour to rethink its heavy focus in China, where it has threatened to pull events if it cannot verify that she is safe and that her allegations are investigated.
content: TURIN, Italy — On a video call and exercise bike as she prepared for tennis practice on Friday, the American player Christina McHale shared memories of matches with her talented former doubles partner, Peng Shuai.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: Amazon Deforestation Soars to 15-Year High
description: Brazil committed this month to end illegal deforestation in eight years, but a government report raises questions about its intent and ability to meet that target.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s pledge this month to end illegal deforestation in eight years drew much praise from global leaders, but an official report this week cast doubt on that commitment after it showed that the rate of deforestation in the Amazon rainforest was at its worst in 15 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becca Foley
title: Chalk It Up to ‘Chill Yentas’
description: Yoelit Lipinsky was not actively looking for love when she was set up with Ariel Greene in a Facebook dating group for Jewish professionals.
content: Yoelit Lipinsky was done with dating when Ariel Greene’s profile came across her computer screen in December 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: A Mermaid Finds Her Captain
description: Kathleen Reardon, who has “an affinity for all things mermaid,” knew Timothy Agra was a good catch when she learned he has a captain’s license.
content: Timothy Agra has a law degree, but it was his captain’s license that made him the perfect match for Kathleen Reardon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick and Benjamin Weiser
title: Manhattan U.S. Attorney Forms New Civil Rights Unit
description: Damian Williams, the first Black U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York, noted a rise in anti-Asian and antisemitic crimes.
content: Citing a rise in hate attacks, Damian Williams, the new U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York, announced the creation of a civil rights unit in the office’s criminal division on Friday at a ceremony at the Harlem Armory, signaling a new focus for one of the country’s most powerful prosecutor’s offices.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: As Capital Chokes in Smog, India’s Leaders Trade Blame
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 19, 2021.
content: “It’s really sad for a nation where every time there is a health emergency the Supreme Court needs to intervene.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘A Ship From Guantánamo.’
description: Moath al-Alwi has been imprisoned for nearly two decades. An Op-Doc video shows how making art is his escape. How can art give us purpose and meaning?
content: Moath al-Alwi has never been charged with a crime, but he has spent over 19 years at the U.S. military detention camp in Cuba.  “A Ship From Guantánamo,” a six and a half-minute Op-Doc video, tells the story of the art he makes to survive — and escape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: Companies Love to Buy Back Their Stock. A Tax Could Deter Them.
description: Supporters of the Biden buyback tax say it will be good for the economy. Skeptics say it will hurt investment.
content: Corporate America has been feeding a stock buyback boom for decades, with companies spending trillions of dollars to repurchase their shares without paying any taxes on those transactions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Canada expands its list of vaccines accepted for travel.
description: Officials also removed a test requirement for eligible travelers re-entering Canada within 72 hours.
content: With the holiday travel season nearing, Canadian officials announced several measures on Friday meant to standardize international travel and make it easier for Canadians taking short trips to re-enter the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: A Superb Shrimp Stew
description: Vallery Lomas’s spicy shrimp Creole delivers weekend depth of flavor in a fraction of the time.
content: I’ll keep this brief this week, as we all run headlong into Thanksgiving, Friendsgiving and — I can’t believe this — the holiday season. At any rate, I’m ready for pie. I’m ready for latkes. I’m ready for cookies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Crawford-Porter Fight a Sign of Crossover Possibility Among Promoters
description: Rival promoters like Top Rank and Premier Boxing Champions have shown more willingness recently to match up their big fighters against one another.
content: How do we know the welterweight title bout, scheduled for Saturday night, between Terence Crawford and Shawn Porter is an important event in the boxing world?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Dwyer
title: She Plays a Young Serena Williams
description: Demi Singleton stars in “King Richard,” opposite Will Smith.
content: Name: Demi Singleton
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: F.D.A. Authorizes Coronavirus Booster Shots for All Adults
description: If the C.D.C. agrees, adults who received a second shot of the Pfizer or Moderna vaccine at least six months ago could be eligible by this weekend.
content: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration on Friday authorized booster shots of both the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines for everyone 18 and older, opening up eligibility to tens of millions more fully vaccinated adults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: Joe Biden Is Succeeding
description: Voters may pummel Democrats next year, but future generations will be grateful.
content: Joe Biden came to the White House at a pivotal moment in American history. We had become a country dividing into two nations, one highly educated and affluent and the other left behind. The economic gaps further inflamed cultural and social gaps, creating an atmosphere of intense polarization, cultural hostility, alienation, bitterness and resentment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Bonnie Sherk, Landscape Artist Full of Surprises, Dies at 76
description: Her artwork included transforming forlorn parcels, sometimes by planting them, other times just by sitting in them.
content: On a Thursday in June 1970, a police officer in San Francisco was going nuts because motorists entering the busy Central Freeway near Market Street were jamming on their brakes, startled by an unusual sight. On what the day before had been a bare patch of ground, a young woman was sitting on a bale of hay, surrounded by potted palm trees and 4,000 square feet of green turf, patting a Guernsey calf that was tied to a railing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: A New General Manager Is a ‘Relief’ for Mets Leadership
description: A lengthy process landed Billy Eppler, formerly of the Angels and the Yankees. Steven Cohen says the deal received “universal praise” from his fellow owners.
content: There are lots of reasons to be encouraged by the hiring of Billy Eppler, who was finally introduced on Friday as the Mets’ new general manager. As a pro scouting director, he helped win a World Series for the Yankees. As a general manager, he signed Shohei Ohtani for the Los Angeles Angels. At 46, he is young enough to appreciate the value of data, but old enough to honor the instincts of scouts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Bettina Plevan, Litigator Who Shattered Glass Ceilings, Dies at 75
description: After her own meteoric rise to partner at Proskauer Rose, where she handled sexual harassment cases, she helped other women advance in the legal profession.
content: Bettina Plevan, a top litigator who made her name defending employers in sexual harassment and gender discrimination cases, and who helped pave the way for women to advance in the legal profession after shattering glass ceilings herself, died on Oct. 29 at a hospital in Manhattan. She was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Don’t Sweat the Naysayers
description: John Hawksley gives us some excellent advice at 55A. And the rest of his puzzle is awesome, too.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — When I started this job in 2011, I already had enough experience as a writer to understand that only my mother was going to adore everything I wrote. I knew intellectually that I couldn’t please everyone, but it still stung when people criticized my style or when the trolls emerged to stir up trouble. For reasons that perhaps only a psychologist could understand — and I know I’m not the only one who feels this way — amid hundreds of accolades, a single barb is what would linger in my brain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: Stephen Petronio Looks to the NYC of His Past for Inspiration
description: The choreographer returns to the East Village — and La MaMa — with “Petronio Punk Picks and Other Delights,” landing in a place of nostalgia.
content: When the pandemic hit, the choreographer Stephen Petronio found himself grappling with the confines of space, especially when creating over Zoom. That experience of restriction, he writes in “In Absentia,” a limited-edition book chronicling his life after the shutdown, reminded him of his early years — specifically a time in the 1980s when his studio space was his living room on St. Marks Place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Review: ‘Cowboy Bebop,’ Minus the Art
description: It’s unfair to compare Netflix’s live-action remake to the anime original. But there’s no really compelling reason to talk about it otherwise.
content: “Cowboy Bebop,” an anime series that ran for one season in Japan 22 years ago, inspires a particular kind of devotion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What’s in the $2.2 Trillion Social Policy and Climate Bill
description: The package includes $400 billion to bolster support for children and families, $555 billion for climate change programs and $166 billion in housing aid.
content: WASHINGTON — The House on Friday passed a sprawling, roughly $2 trillion social policy, climate and tax measure that is the central pillar of President Biden’s domestic agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Hutchinson
title: How to Save Your Knees Without Giving Up Your Workout
description: There’s no magic bullet to knee health, but staying active and building muscles around the joint are crucial.
content: In the annals of unsolicited advice, few nuggets have been dispensed as widely and with less supporting evidence than this: “If you keep doing all that running, you’re going to ruin your knees.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Roston and Matt McCann
title: Did You Miss the Lunar Eclipse? Here’s What It Looked Like.
description: The partial eclipse on Thursday night and Friday morning lasted more than six hours, and these photos captured the moon’s rust-red hue.
content: If you slept through the latest partial lunar eclipse, we cannot fault you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Abrams
title: The Inspiration for ‘Malfunction: The Dressing Down of Janet Jackson’
description: The New York Times’s latest documentary, premiering Friday, examines the scandal surrounding the performer following the 2004 Super Bowl halftime show.
content: Do you remember the Justin Timberlake Super Bowl incident? Or maybe you think of it the way most people do — as the Janet Jackson scandal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Judge Tries to Block New York Times’s Coverage of Project Veritas
description: The state court order, which The Times said it would immediately oppose, raised concerns from First Amendment advocates.
content: A New York trial court judge ordered The New York Times on Thursday to temporarily refrain from publishing or seeking out certain documents related to the conservative group Project Veritas, an unusual instance of a court blocking coverage by a major news organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a Polish procedural, a Kazakh dark comedy, a Tunisian social-realist drama, and more.
content: In the age of streaming, the earth is flat — screen-size — with travel to faraway destinations only a monthly subscription and a click away. We’ve journeyed through the world of options and chosen the best new international movies for you to watch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: The G.O.P. Has a Bad Men Problem
description: The creeping not-so-casual misogyny is indicative of the dark path down which former President Donald Trump continues to lead the G.O.P.
content: How upbeat is the Republican Party about its prospects for taking control of the House and Senate next year? So upbeat that it apparently is cool with the fact that in three Senate races — Georgia, Missouri and Pennsylvania — it has leading candidates who have been accused of harassing, abusing, threatening or otherwise mistreating women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Caroline Todd, Half of a Mystery-Writing Duo, Dies at 86
description: Writing under the pen name Charles Todd, she and her son published nearly 40 mystery novels, all of them set in rural England just after World War I.
content: Many mystery writers publish under a pen name. Caroline Todd may have been the only one to use two at the same time, one masking the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: One meme stock lawsuit against Robinhood is dismissed, but others loom.
description: The suit was part of a proposed three-part class action suit against Robinhood and others over their roles in January’s GameStop trading frenzy.
content: A federal court in Florida this week dismissed one part of a proposed three-part class action lawsuit against Robinhood and others over their roles in January’s GameStop trading frenzy. Investors alleged that brokerage firms like Robinhood conspired with clearinghouses and the market maker Citadel Securities to restrict trading of meme stocks as they shot up in price. And no, audiobooks are not just some lesser form of a print book.
